quoteLast: the 1st Battalion Grenadiers passed through the leading battalions and attacked the third objective; but, as the left flank was still exposed, the result was the same――the right got well forward while the left écheloned back and dug in. To fill the gaps the Welsh Guards were sent up, and thus a continuous line, nearly 1400 yards long, was made, protecting the left flank of the Division.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

quoteFirst: The soil a dark loam of good quality, but very wet in the rainy season. At 11.30 a.m. came on a large creek or river with many sandy channels in which only a few small pools of water remained; followed it up to the east-south-east through fine open grassy flats till
quoteLast: and camped in the bed of the river. The banks of the river (which is probably the Gilbert of Leichhardt) are well grassed, and a dense line of melaleuca, leucodendron, flooded-gum, and morinda, mark its course through the plain; but being divided into many channels its size is difficult to ascertain.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteLast: !  Nearly two hours, and I didn't believe it was two minutes!  Is it possible that this clock is humbugging again? Miss Ethelton!  Just one moment, please.  Are you there yet?"
title: The Entire Project Gutenberg Works of Mark Twain
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteFirst: Swan River (Riviere des Cygnes) upon this part of the coast, latitude 31 degrees
quoteLast: 2 degrees, was examined by the French expedition, to the distance of about twenty leagues from its mouth; and found still to contain salt water. The rock in its neighbourhood consisted altogether of sandy and calcareous incrustations, in horizontal beds, enclosing, it is stated, shells, and the roots and even trunks of trees.
title:
Narrative of a Survey of the Intertropical and Western Coasts of Australia — Vol. 2
Performed between the years 1818 and 1822
author: King, Philip Parker, 1793-1856

quoteFirst: Resumed our journey down the river at 8.5 a.m., the general course being east; at
quoteLast: camped at a nymphae pool in one of the side channels of the river. The country was now more level and open, with grassy flats along the river, but the back country rose into low rocky sandstone hills, thinly clothed with white-gum and triodia.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

title:
A Flight in Spring
In the car Lucania from New York to the Pacific coast and back, during April and May, 1898
author: Knowles, J. Harris (John Harris), 1832-1908

quoteFirst: As time passed, however, and no reports of enemy vessels being sighted came in from our light cruisers, it became evident that the High Sea Fleet had turned back, probably owing to the fact that the Zeppelins had warned the German Commander-in-Chief of our presence and movements. On this assumption, at
quoteLast: I directed Commodore Tyrwhitt to steer for a position to the north-westward of Terschelling, so that he might be ready to deliver a night attack on the enemy’s fleet with the Harwich force.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: You see, in Mariposa, shaving isn't the hurried, perfunctory thing that it is in the city. A shave is looked upon as a form of physical pleasure and lasts anywhere from
title: Sunshine Sketches of a Little Town
author: Leacock, Stephen, 1869-1944

quoteFirst: He looked at his watch as he ran--only
quoteLast: ! barely five minutes since he had signalled to Arthur!  Jerry relaxed his speed--it was scarcely possible that Miss Meredon was near Silverthorns yet.
title: Silverthorns
author: Molesworth, Mrs., 1839-1921; Paton, J. Noël (Joseph Noël), Sir, 1821-1901 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , Wednesday afternoon, Uncle Joe's train came into the station, and Uncle Joe got out and shouted among his relatives. At eighteen minutes before three he was waving to them from the platform of the last car, having just slipped a two-dollar bill into Penrod's breast-pocket.
title: Penrod and Sam
author: Tarkington, Booth, 1869-1946

title:
A Flight in Spring
In the car Lucania from New York to the Pacific coast and back, during April and May, 1898
author: Knowles, J. Harris (John Harris), 1832-1908

quoteLast: a considerable amount of smoke was sighted to the eastward. This made it clear that the enemy was to the northward and eastward, and that it would be impossible for him to round the Horn Reef without being brought to action. Course was accordingly altered to the eastward and subsequently to north-eastward, the enemy being sighted at 3.31 p.m. Their force consisted of five battle-cruisers.
title: World's War Events, Vol. II
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873-1940 [Editor]

quoteLast: , and at 3.40 P.M. Mr. Loomis sent the telegram which he had already prepared to both Panama and Colon. Apparently, however, the consul-general at Panama had not received the information embodied in the Associated Press bulletin, upon which the Assistant Secretary of State based his dispatch; for his answer was that there was no uprising, although the situation was critical, this answer being received at 8.15 P.M. Immediately afterward he sent another dispatch, which was received at 9.50 P.M., saying that the uprising had occurred, and had been successful, with
title: Presidential addresses and state papers, Volume 2 (of 7)
author: Roosevelt, Theodore, 1858-1919

title:
The Comedy & Tragedy of the Second Empire
Paris Society in the Sixties; Including Letters of Napoleon III., M. Pietri, and Comte de la Chapelle, and Portraits of the Period
author: Legge, Edward, -1927

quoteFirst: "Your calculation is that as the accident took place at 3:12 and you left at
quoteLast: you drove fifteen miles in thirty-seven minutes--that is to say, at the rate of twenty-four miles an hour. Is that right?"
title: Manslaughter
author: Miller, Alice Duer, 1874-1942; Gruger, Frederic Rodrigo, 1871-1953 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The weather on August 27, while mostly sunny, included occasional snow or sleet flurries; the northerly wind was brisk to strong; and the temperature, ranging from 37° to 50°, prevented the appearance of black flies. By 10:20 a.m. a band of about 10 does and fawns crossed the rapid on Little River. Two hours later 12-15 animals followed the same course, and presently 75-100 passed upstream on the far side, with a good deal of grunting. About
quoteLast: nearly a hundred Caribou, perhaps alarmed by a passing plane, dashed north out of the Eastern Bog. By 4:45 p.m. 20 or more bucks, does, and fawns swam across Little River at its mouth; several of the biggest bucks, with enormous antlers, led the advance into the water.
title: The Barren Ground Caribou of Keewatin
author: Harper, Francis, 1886-1972

quoteLast: these two brigades advanced and partially restored the situation on the front Givenchy--Festubert, driving the enemy out of Givenchy. The 2nd Brigade (2nd Batt. R. Sussex Regt., 1st Batt. N. Lancs, 1st Batt. Northants Regt., 2nd Batt. K.R.R.
